user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleTask_Entry:
```c
static void *OS_ConsoleTask_Entry(void *arg)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t           local_arg;
    OS_impl_console_internal_record_t *local;
    OS_object_token_t                  token;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    local_arg.opaque_arg = arg;
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE, local_arg.id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_console_table, token);

        /* Loop forever (unless shutdown is set) */
        while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
        {
            OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&token);
            sem_wait(&local->data_sem);
        }
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }
    return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ConsoleTask_Entry:
typedef union
{
    void *           opaque_arg;
    OS_ArgCallback_t arg_callback_func;
    osal_id_t        id;
    osal_index_t     idx;
} OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only function parameter of OS_ConsoleTask_Entry is 'arg'. There are no assignments to 'arg' anywhere in the function (no occurrences of ‘arg = ...’), so the pointer parameter itself is not modified. The line local_arg.opaque_arg = arg reads the parameter into a local union — this is a read, not a modification of the parameter variable. Subsequent uses (local_arg.id) read the union contents; they do not modify the original parameter. The other modifications observed (e.g., token->obj_id inside OS_ObjectIdGetById, passing &token to OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl, sem_wait(&local->data_sem)) act on local variables or on objects referenced by local pointers, not on the function parameter itself. Therefore, with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified), there are no suspicious fragments in the provided code that require further investigation.
